prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Deblending of Herschel sources with deep ALMA 1.1mm imaging

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We intend to cover each of our Herschel-selected sources by using ALMA pointings with a FOV of ~22.7" in Band 6. The close correlation between 350um and 500um allowed us to narrow down the location of 500um priors to the PSF FWHM of Herschel at 350um of only 24.9", hence very well matched with the ALMA FOV in Band 6 of 22.7". Using the ALMA Observing Tool (OT), and based on the extrapolated flux densities from the best-fit SED to the FIR photometry (~1-4 mJy in the 1.1mm), we have calculated that with a 2 min integration time per source, we can achieve rms noise levels of 0.104 mJy over a bandwidth of 268 GHz at 276 GHz, which will provide a >10 sigma detection for the dominant sources in each Herschel 500um beam and down to 4 sigma for the faintest contributors in some of our targets. We anticipate there will be ~50 sources to be detected with ALMA for all pointings. Accounting for the uncertainties in the dust temperature in estimating the 1.1mm flux densities (a factor of ~3-4 lower), the proposed ALMA observations can still detect the dominant sources at sigma level. The spatial resolution is 1.3" at Band 6 for most compact 12m configuration, which is enough to achieve our science goal. The total requested time is 1.3 hours, including the overheads and calibrators.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent (Sub)millimeter and Herschel observations have detected a significant population of z>2 starbursts, which could dominate the total bolometric emission of galaxies at those epochs. However, source confusion, especially at 500um and lack of identification of counterparts limits our understanding the nature of the infrared starburst population. We propose ALMA follow-up observations of a sample of FIR-selected dust obscured galaxies which present high 500um to 24um flux ratios. Our principal goal is to obtain sensitive ALMA continuum observations at Band 6 (1mm) to identify the counterparts of FIR detections by resolving them into individual sources, and to determine the dust temperature (and thus dust mass) for distant galaxies. The proposed ALMA observations will help to unveil a missing population of faint distant galaxies, providing new insight into the galaxy evolution and star-formation history in the Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
